name: Weir Farm National Historical Park
description: Visit the home and studio of America's most beloved Impressionist, J. Alden Weir, and walk in the footsteps of generations of world-class artists. Set amidst more than 60 acres of painterly woods, fields, and waterways, you’ll soon see why Weir described his home as the "Great Good Place." Weir’s farm is a national legacy to American Impressionism, the creative spirit, and historic preservation.
shortDescription: Visit the home and studio of America's most beloved Impressionist, J. Alden Weir, and walk in the footsteps of generations of world-class artists. Set amidst more than 60 acres of painterly woods, fie...

operatingHours.description: Park grounds, trails and parking lot are open everyday from Sunrise to Sunset.

climate.weatherDescription: Weir Farm’s grounds are open all year and each season offers a unique experience. For a comfortable visit please note the following information. Winter: Temperatures average from 20 F to 40 F. Storms and colder weather are possible. Spring: Temperatures average from 30 F to 70 F. Rain is common. Summer: Temperatures average from 60 F to 85 F. High humidity is common in July and August. Fall: Temperatures average from 35 F to 75 F. Foliage season runs from mid-September to mid-to-late October.

images.title: Weir House
images.altText: A view of the south side of the Weir House with porch visable, showing a fence in front of the home
images.caption: The Weir House was home to three generations of artists, beginning with Impressionist painter Julian Alden Weir in 1882.

images.title: Living Room of the Weir House
images.altText: The inside of a living room with two arm chairs and a table in between.
images.caption: Weir House tours are offered seasonally, Wednesday through Sunday.

images.title: Plein Air Painting of Weir Studio
images.altText: A painting of a red building with the same building in the background.
images.caption: An oil painting of Weir Studio by artist Mary Burkhardt at Weir Farm National Historical Park.

images.title: The Inside of the Young Studio
images.altText: The inside of a studio with several northern windows, paintings, sculptures, and art supplies.
images.caption: The Young Studio has been restored to circa-1940 and is historically furnished. Mahonri Young once owned many of the furnishings and art supplies in the building.

images.title: Weir Barn
images.altText: An wooden barn with the slider door open and a wooden fence around the sides.
images.caption: The Weir Barn and its outbuildings - the tack house, chicken coop, ice house, and corn crib - were crucial to the working farm.

images.title: Weir Pond
images.altText: A large still pond in the foreground reflects the tree line that rims the pond.
images.caption: Weir Pond was built in 1896 after Julian Alden Weir won 1st prize at the Boston Art Club Exposition.
